text: Not reliable. I ordered 2 items. But they never delivered. Never again will I order from Amazon.
text_clean: Not reliable. I ordered 2 items. But they never delivered. Never again will I order from Amazon.

text:
Amazon has effectively established a monopoly, delivering millions of parcels every day, yet showing little regard for the customers who sustain it. The customer service is perfunctory at best; while they do respond, the agents appear trained more to frustrate than to assist. The company employs some of the poorest couriers, who frequently leave parcels unattended, and obtaining a refund in such cases becomes almost impossible. Instead of taking responsibility, Amazon diverts customers with automated emails instructing them to report the item as stolen, even when it was left in a public or communal area. 
 

 Returns are equally problematic. Items are sometimes not registered upon arrival, leading to customers being charged again for products they have already sent back. Amazon behaves this way because it knows people will continue to buy from them: it is quick and convenient, even when identical items can be found elsewhere, such as on Temu, for a fraction of the price. In many cases, Amazon charges ten times more for the same cheaply manufactured goods. 
 

 It is time for consumers to reconsider their reliance on this corporate giant, which prioritises profit over people. Despite spending ¬£6,000 on Amazon last year and returning fewer than 7% of my purchases, I still received an email warning that my account might be closed due to "excessive returns". This demonstrates precisely how little the company values its customers.

Instead of taking responsibility, Amazon diverts customers with automated emails instructing them to report the item as stolen, even when it was left in a public or communal area. Returns are equally problematic. Items are sometimes not registered upon arrival, leading to customers being charged again for products they have already sent back. Amazon behaves this way because it knows people will continue to buy from them: it is quick and convenient, even when identical items can be found elsewhere, such as on Temu, for a fraction of the price. In many cases, Amazon charges ten times more for the same cheaply manufactured goods. It is time for consumers to reconsider their reliance on this corporate giant, which prioritises profit over people. Despite spending 6,000 on Amazon last year and returning fewer than 7 of my purchases, I still received an email warning that my account might be closed due to "excessive returns". This demonstrates precisely how little the company values its customers.

text: Rip off free 30 day trial. I accepted the free 30 day prime trial which I accepted through my amazon account app. I then cancelled the offer 30 days after but they still took out the ¬£8.99 fee from my bank account without my permission. I rang amazon on the 24th November 2025 to tell them had cancelled and requested a full credit. After 40 minutes on the phone the Amazon representative agreed and said that my request had been accepted. I rang amazon back again on the 04th December asking where was my refund. After speaking to 2 amazon representatives and approximately an hour on the phone they hid behind Google play saying I would need to speak to them. I told them I accepted the free offer through the amazon app and cancelled it through the amazon app, nothing to do with Google play. I requested a copy of the call I made on the 24th November 2025 which I am still waiting for and where they confirmed I would receive my full refund. I cancelled an amazon order I had pending and I will not purchase anything from amazon until this is resolved. To me this free offer is nothing but a scam, don't take it up. I have spent thousands through the amazon app but never again.

text: The worst purchase and customer service in my life. Before this I had never ordered food products from Amazon and now I know why. I ordered $175 worth of GROCERIES and then my order updated to a shipping date 6 weeks away! I contacted them and it took chatting with three people to get an answer. The items were coming from a warehouse further away. Okay, so I waited. When they started shipping the products they all came in different boxes and on different days. One bag of lentils came in an envelope alone. They shipped a single bag of lentils instead of putting them in one of the boxes, wasteful! At least that bag of lentils arrived in tact. Another bag that was in one of the boxes ripped open and was a huge mess everywhere, even had to vacuum! Then after waiting 6 weeks and them having my money for 6 weeks they cancel a quarter of the order and send me a refund for those items. Lol what an absolute CLOWN SHOW! I'll never order groceries from Amazon again, lesson learned.

text: I purchased an electric standing desk that failed in under six months with very light use. When I contacted the seller through Amazon messaging, they offered a refund but also "suggested" that I revise my review. After I accepted the refund without addressing the review suggestion, the seller emailed my personal account and told me to change the review first before they would send the refund. This violates Amazon's policies on review manipulation and off-platform communication. I reported everything to Amazon with screenshots. The first chat agent said the issue would be escalated, but I never received any follow-up. In a second chat, I was transferred through multiple representatives, had to resend screenshots, and repeatedly heard that the "return window had closed" --- even though this was not a standard return issue. Again, I was told it would be escalated, but no follow-up ever came. Amazon's response was inconsistent and ultimately unhelpful. When a seller violates clear policies, customers should not be left without resolution.

text: If I could give zero stars, I absolutely would. The delivery drivers are horrendous, leaving parcels in carparks, at wrong addresses (If I wanted to be a delivery driver i would be, I have to go searching for my parcels!!!)arriving later than advertised (by a day) several times, not bothering to knock at the door, just leave parcels on doorsteps out in the open, or thrown over the 6 ft fence!!!! It's not worth paying for prime or complaining anymore because they don't care. After the last debacle I was promised ¬£10 credit ... Never happened. That said I'd rather have my parcels delivered on time, with care and to my address than be compensated for error after error. Absolutely shocking üò°

author_id: That Guy's One of a Kind
text: While my experience with Amazon has been superior to Tamu, Light in the Box and others who pedal Chinese products. I want to warn you about Amazon/vine and the DEBT being TRANSFERRED through this vine TO YOU. The Vine allows Amazon to write off products at full Retail value by giving you product "for services" that IRS recognizes as TAXABLE INCOME. Above and beyond the fact people are getting paid to write reviews that get rejected if they are critical or "racist" ("made in China" is racism), I feel like I have been party to a money laundering scheme. I even had a former IRS agent tell me flat out, this sounds like money laundering, and YOU are party to it. You see, INSTEAD of WRITING OFF the WHOLESALE value of unsellable items (perhaps items that have been returned in unsellable condition) they pay people "viners" "for services" by giving them these products which the IRS considers as cash payment at the RETAIL VALUE of the item. Not only does this mean Amazon can now write off the full RETAIL VALUE (around twice as much) the viner has to pay Income Tax on the full retail value of the item. I wrote to Amazon several times without reply about this. I called customer support and the person had never even heard of Amazon Vine. (I tried to return defective items and the agent always says, "Sir, I cannot give you a refund or replacement because you did not pay for this item." I found that if I insist on returning something without replacement or refund, I was able to return items for a ZERO DOLLAR RETURN. but it did not change the amount shown on the running total listed in my account under form 1099. In other words, Amazon just got something back they paid nothing for and can once again write off for full retail value. I don't know if it is money laundering, but it is one heck of a money making scheme. Amazon has tons of stuff that doesn't sell that they have to store, move, and return to make room for more product. They have turned this wholesale loss into Retail Profits. BTW, after a review is posted, you cannot return the item because it is "used." It wasn't "used" by the person who put it back in the box improperly or without some of the parts, but after you reviewed the item, it becomes used. You cannot return it. You are stuck with it and you have to pay INCOME tax. I was told by Amazon at sign up, "You MIGHT have to pay tax on some of these items." I thought they meant SALES TAX or USE TAX. I did not get a paper 1099 EVER. So how would I know? They posted one in my "account" at Amazon.com at the end of the full year telling that I would likely have to pay around 20% (which there is no way they could possibly know what other income I might have which would greatly affect the amount of tax I owe on ALL of my income back to the first penny I earned that year). BTW, If I were to sell this stuff (as used because I had to use it to review it) I have to pay income tax on the full amount including shipping and commissions or other fees. $216k in product paid to me and reported to the IRS as "payment for services" which the IRS records as CASH MONEY paid as Income. As the year was coming to an end, I increased the fervor of my attempt to get information. About two weeks into this, I got a notice while I was writing reviews that said, "We have noticed irregularities in your reviews. All of your reviews have been removed and you are no longer allowed to review items. You will no longer be able to select items. I never got an explanation of the irregularities. I would caution the general public about the reviews on Amazon. As you will find in the reviews here on Trustpilot, people get banned from writing reviews without being told why they are removed.. Even saying "lower quality made in China product" would get the review rejected as "racist." and writing a few more reviews like this will get you banned, and they do not tell you why. Even when they reject your reviews the first time they are often so vague about it you have to guess what they want removed and a lot of reviewers just remove anything negative in order to save time. To the people being solicited for the vine, I caution you. I read warnings from people going back several years and I thought I was better and smarter than they were. But when you consider that once you review the item it is considered to be "used." You cannot return it and you cannot sell it as new. Any warranty will be rendered null and void by transfer to another person. And when you realize you have to pay INCOME TAX (between 20 and 30 percent) at full retail value when you get paid with this item , and you pay taxes (between 20 and 30 percent) on the full price you sell it for PLUS tax on shipping and commissions and fees. All this is income to the IRS. But when you take all this into account (and there is more) when you get to the point where you pay Amazon their fees and any advertising you do, there is nothing left
